Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Methods for Creating Passive Solar Window Film using Using Novel Dyes for Improved Energy Efficiency in Buildings
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will be the development of an effective approach to energy reduction in residential and commercial settings using film materials on building windows. Windows coated with passive solar film created in this project will help limit the amount of infrared and ultraviolet light entering a building. This lowers the amount of heat accumulating within the building and reduces the need for air conditioning. Importantly, this approach can be used in both new buildings and old buildings. The proposed materials can yield up to 50% energy savings for air conditioning. The novel process used in this project enhances the thermal stability of cyanine dyes up to 300 degrees Celsius, allowing for incorporation of the these dyes into inks, polymer pellets and films with protection from thermal degradation. This thermal stability would allow the nanomaterial to be incorporated into high-density polymers such as polycarbonates, polyimides and Teflon, which would allow use of inexpensive dyes to take advantage of the enhanced polymer structural stability for versatile and durable applications. The dyes are significantly less expensive than the porphyrin dyes or sputter-coated Indium-Tin oxide-Silver-Gold materials, and are potentially simpler to process into functional products for passive solar applications.

The technical objectives of this Phase I research project are to develop low-cost, thermally stabilized organic dyes to absorb specific wavelengths of ultraviolet and near-infrared for passive solar application on windows in commercial and residential facilities. This will be accomplished by adding a functional group at the end of an organic dye chain of carbon groups in order to strategically bind the dyes to a metal oxide nanoparticle. The chemical functional groups reside on side chains that are easily modified by simple chemical reactions, and the change has no effect on the chromophore so the dyes? ability to filter specific wavelengths of light are not disturbed. This has been demonstrated with several model dye compounds with various binding chemical functional groups. These modifications thermally stabilize organic dyes so they can survive high polymer extrusion temperatures without the need for hazardous organic solvents. The research objectives include the incorporation of dye bound to ZnO nanoparticles into polymers through melt extrusion; development and modification of dyes to absorb in specified wavelength ranges; binding of model dye(s) to ZnO nanoparticles and determination of optical and thermal stability; and scaling up the electrochemical process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ChromaNanoTech LLC is exploring production of optical nanomaterials in polymer films for use in residential windows as passive solar treatments. This optical nanomaterial can selectively block infrared light from the sun, which contributes to the heat component of light but not the visible. By blocking the infrared portion of light, the treatment reduced the incoming heat, which alleviates the demand for air conditioning of a home thereby reducing electrical costs. This technology is well known in the construction industry as passive solar for commercial and institutional buildings. The National Science Foundation's support of ChromaNanoTech has led to several major advancements that will solidify ChromaNanoTech production capability to supply to the passive solar market enabling a low cost passive solar window treatment for the residential market. ChromaNanoTech accomplished the production of the optical nanomaterial by electrochemically binding low cost organic dyes to metal oxide which led to its large increase in thermal stability allowing the optical material to survive industrial processing to which the base dyes alone would be incapable.

 The Phase I Small Business Innovation Research grant has helped ChromaNanoTech develop enhancements to the production systems and optical material itself. Optical material was generated and incorporated into masterbatch pellets, which concentrates the optical material in an acrylate plastic. These masterbatch pellets are widely used in the plastics industry. Once incorporated, the masterbatch pellet can be further diluted and extruded as a window film, termed a hard coat which is widely used as a window treatment. This film retained the optical properties of the optical material which displayed the success of the ChromaNanoTech technology. 

One of the hardest tasks is scaling the material so the process is cost effective. ChromaNanoTech was able to make considerable progress on scaling in a prototype production line by altering the conditions and the setup of the reaction. This research allowed for a 95% increase in production capacity while it decreased the post processing time by more than one third. Furthermore, ChromaNanoTech has made a significant advancement towards decreasing the particle size. Before the National Science Foundation's SBIR grant, ChromaNanoTech was generating optical material with diameter sizes of average 220 nanometers or more. While still very small, these particles may also agglomerate, to sizes which are within the visible range of human eyesight and would lead to an opaque window due to light scattering. By altering the temperature and chemical conditions, the optical nanomaterial was able to average less than 100 nanometers, at approximately 90 nanometers, which would produce little light scattering when evaluated in films.

ChromaNanoTech has also expanded the catalog of dyes that are usable in the electrochemical preparation process. Twelve new dyes have been identified and of these three have been tested. One of the new dyes absorbs in the ultraviolet, allowing the future ChromaNanoTech window films to potentially prevent sun damage to furnishings in homes. The other two absorb in the infrared, allowing a broader spectral coverage of the heat blocking film. These two were analogs of each other, with the major difference being the way the dye may be anchored to the metal oxide. By researching into the new anchoring group, ChromNanoTech will be able to introduce more diverse types of dyes into the final passive solar window film. These new dyes have undergone extensive testing and show considerable thermal stability and retain optical properties. We have also shown fluorescence, which is the materials’ ability to emit light after irradiation, can be modified through this nanoparticle processing of the dye, allowing on/off like control based on the dyes structure. 

In summary, the National Science Foundation's support has allowed considerable progress of the research and development that ChromaNanoTech needed to develop its materials for window treatments for passive solar application.  ChromaNanoTech was able to make significant advancements towards generating an optical window film that blocks the heat component of light. A prototype of the film has already been generated and tested through collaboration with a business partner. New advancements to the electrochemical process for generating these optical nanomaterials have been discovered and when fully qualified will increase production capacity of ChromaNanoTech to allow for large scale production and sales at a low cost. ChromaNanoTech has also been able to reduce the size of the nanomaterial under 100 nanometers, which is conducive to a clear window. Lastly, new types of organic dyes have been tested increasing the catalog of ChromaNanoTech optical materials from a supplying partner as well as allowing access to new types of organic dyes. ChromaNanoTech LLC plans to move forward with phase II funding to develop and qualify large scale production capability.
